column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	25	First of all

column3: frankly
column4: I am perplexed at Professor Honohan's belief in and commitment to competition as the way to sort out some of the issues that confront us. He has not really made the case for it. For example

column6: that is
column7: the State setting interest rates - even though he seems to suggest that they should be reduced and that there is an element of profiteering going on. However

column9: but without any real argument to sustain that. It was precisely the dynamic of competition that led to the bubble
column10: uncontrolled lending and the crash that followed

Professor Honohan finished his contribution by saying that the banks have been damagingly slow in resolving the mortgage arrears crisis. That is a good case for administrative control
column12: as are variable interest rates and what is happening in the whole property area. I would also like to hear Professor Honohan's comments on that. It is extremely worrying that property prices are going out of control
column13: as that was such a big contributory factor to the crash. We had property prices going out of control
column14: and people with low incomes were borrowing money they really could not afford
column15: while chasing property whose prices were going through the roof. That also led to the crash. I do not see
column17: how Professor Honohan can support his argument that
column18: faced with these serious challenges and problems and the experience that we have just been through
column19: the answer we have to get back to is competition.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	26	A number of things arise from that. Deputy Boyd Barrett might have a different perspective about ways of organising the economy in general
column2: so we can obviously agree to differ on that. I am subject to the treaty
column3: so I am thinking in terms of an economy in which one has multiple service providers that operate in a competitive manner and price control is limited to cases in which there are clear reasons for market failure. There are clear reasons for market failure in banking. We do control a lot of stuff in banking. For example
column4: on the Deputy's particular point about property prices
column5: the way things were going and bubbles
column6: our interventions on loan-to-value and loan-to-income ratios - unpopular though they were
column7: in some quarters anyway - are a good example of working in an environment in which the banks did not like what we were doing. All of the banks wrote in to say they did not like it
column8: that they hated it and that it was unnecessary
column9: etc.
column11: they sort of knew that this was par for the course and that they could and would be constrained in what they could lend
column12: having shown that they had in the past loaned too much to people who could not afford to service their debts. The control of retail interest rates in the banking system is a kind of Rubicon
column15: when that was very prevalent. To come out now as a country in the middle of this and say
column16: "We're going to be the country that controls interest rates"
column17: has a signalling value far in excess of what one might think in terms of causing a retreat of service providers. That is my perception of it.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	27	It is precisely that. column2: which is that it will have a chilling effect in terms of providers.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	28	Yes
column2: because I do not want a monopoly banking system. If we decided as a nation that we wanted to work with just two or three banks that would be specialised and would jump on the instruction of some Government Departments
column3: that is an entirely different way. Such systems have shown themselves to be very dysfunctional around the world
column4: so I am certainly not going to encourage somebody to go in that direction. The worst of all would be a halfway house in which we pretend that we are in one system and not in the other. One might say: "It cannot do much harm. You get reasonable people in the Central Bank. They can set a reasonable rate and that will be all right." First of all
column5: however
column6: that is not the way it will be perceived. Second
column7: in committees such as this or in the political system in general
column8: where will the advocacy for higher interest rates come from? It will not be there
column9: so once one starts down this road it will be very difficult to convince anybody that they will ever be allowed to make a reasonable return on their investment.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	29	With time against us
column2: I will agree to disagree with Professor Honohan. To be honest
column3: however
column4: everything he is saying points in the direction of greater administrative control and planning in the economy as a whole
column5: rather than letting the market rip. It all points in that direction. I am not really quite sure how Professor Honohan can act or intervene. In some ways
column6: he is saying that we are pretty powerless here.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	30	We actually intervene a lot. We require them to hold more capital
column2: we have the macro-prudential loan-to-value ratios
column3: and all sorts of restrictions on the way they behave to consumers
column4: which they regard as very burdensome. I want to get away from the idea that the Central Bank is trying to protect the banks rather than the consumer. It is the other way around. column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	31	For the record
column2: no matter what provisions Professor Honohan makes against it

column9: as against
column11: the US Federal Reserve. What does Professor Honohan think of that? The issue of property was at the centre of the previous crisis and it is coming into view again. As time is running out

column13: which was in the statement that Professor Honohan put out in the last few days.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	34	They are very interesting questions. column2: which is a new statistical approach from the CSO
column3: so it goes towards reducing the Government's debt
column4: not its deficit. It is of real benefit to the Irish people. A part of the profits is coming from the income on the portfolio of assets that the Central Bank is allowed to hold because it is part of the euro system and matches the currency issue. Correspondingly
column5: the Central Bank has investments
column6: mainly in Government securities
column7: mainly foreign but also some Irish. It receives interest on that and because the Central Bank is charged internally at the ECB's policy rate
column8: the profit component of that is now very large.That is part of our profit. Another very large part of it
column9: however
column10: comes from the fallout of the IBRC or Anglo Irish Bank liquidation. column11: especially as interest rates are lower and the conditions for selling the bonds into the market are more favourable. This actually increases and accelerates the profits. Last year's profits were at record levels and this will continue to be the case for some time I expect. This is a significant claw-back indirectly through very complicated accounting arrangements of the Central Bank.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	35	I asked about the mandate of central banks.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	36	Many say the ECB's mandate is solely price stability and
column2: of course
column3: that has been emphasised to the extreme
column4: but it is not its sole mandate. Subject to achieving that mandate

column10: but now it is at European level. One needs to be careful about giving too much power to an entity that must balance issues which should be balanced politically
column11: not by appointed persons. I often laugh to myself when I hear people say the Central Bank is not doing this or that. I am thinking

column14: trying to have the issue of mortgage arrears fixed
column15: whatever one says about how we have done it
column16: we are doing a number of things that would be considered to be very much on the outskirts and the extreme edge of our mandate.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	92	The thing about this whole central banking area is a question of balancing. The reason quantitative easing has been adopted is that the way things were going
column2: including oil price rises and the weak demand in the euro area
column3: prospective inflation was getting lower and lower and expectations of future inflation were getting lower and lower. People were beginning to not believe that even on a medium-term horizon the ECB could get back to 2% but that
column4: instead
column5: it would be bouncing around 0% or negative. Step-by-step additional actions were taken
column6: and quantitative easing
column7: which involves the purchase of large quantities of Government bonds from throughout Europe
column8: is a tool which has been reasonably effective in the US
column9: Britain and Japan
column10: so why would we not use it? Not using it would make it seem as though the ECB did not really care
column11: so we definitely had to use this tool. Does it risk pushing things in the other direction? If one has been pushing and pushing and not getting there and then one uses a very strong tool
column12: I suppose there could be some risk of this type
column13: but this would emerge not so much as an overshoot of price inflation
column14: but as a risk that people might take excessive gambles with money that is almost free. What is the benefit to Ireland and when we have seen the problems caused by money that is almost free? column15: so they should not worry about it. That is just to be facetious. In Ireland
column16: where this is really having an effect is not in the availability of borrowing for builders or home owners but in the low cost of refinancing the Government's debt. The NTMA has already refinanced loans from the IMF
column18: to a very low interest rate. It has an effect on the channelling of the profits of the Central Bank
column19: which is a very large sum of money
column20: and will continue over a number of years. This really strong benefit to the public finances has been a boon to Ireland
column21: where over-indebtedness of public finances is a burden. In addition
column22: tracker mortgage holders have seen this come through immediately. Many people in Ireland are paying approximately 1%
column24: on their tracker mortgages. These include people who borrowed at the height of the boom
column25: and probably borrowed more than they ever should have
column26: and it is certainly easing their budget. They will not go out and buy another house. column27: but it has been an unmitigated plus for the Irish economy.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	96	Why is the process regarding mortgage arrears moving so slowly? That would have been the quick way to do it and that is how they did it in America. They had many repossessions. We started with moratoriums on that in 2009 and so forth. We warned about doing anything rashly. Then we moved to engagement and so forth. I am glad we have not had that huge wave of repossessions and that there has been time for the economy to make this recovery
column2: for property prices to bounce back from their nadir and for people to start getting jobs again. There is a definite plus there relative to a quick resolution
column3: which would have been a harsh resolution. That would have been socially damaging. The banks remained over-optimistic all along and are still over-optimistic regarding what they can recover. column4: because the ECB will be looking at that
column5: but our staff were very much involved in it. There will be a temptation for banks to write-back provisions on the basis of optimism that everything is going to be all right. That optimism has caused them to be slow to do anything because
column6: for example
column7: establishing a split mortgage would be a hassle and although the split would allow them to recover if things improved
column8: they would not see the need to do that and would just leave the person on interest-only for a few months. In addition
column9: some of the work we did to provide massive amounts of very cheap liquidity to the banks took the pressure off. column17: thinking that they could not do this. We had a deeper crisis than most of the others

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2015-05-28 00:00:00	Overview of the Banking Sector: Central Bank of Ireland	115	I will begin by responding to the questions asked about quantitative easing and inflation. I should not be talking about this at all
column2: given that we are in the quiet period before the monetary policy meeting that will take place next Tuesday and Wednesday. While I will make an exception
column3: I will not talk about current monetary policy decisions
column4: rather I will talk about quantitative easing in general terms. I hope that will be acceptable.  There is a clear answer to the question asked by Deputy Sean Fleming about the 2% rate. The measurement of inflation is not very good at taking account of quality improvements and new goods. There have been studies of this in the past 20 or 30 years
column5: particularly in the United States where there is quite a body of evidence and the data are super. The US authorities asked how much of a difference it would make if they could take proper account of new goods and quality improvements. They came up with the conclusion that it was the driver of the figure of 2%. I do not remember exactly what it was
column6: but they more or less said that if one year was taken over the next
column7: the rate was probably 2%. The real rate of inflation is 0% when the rate is 2%
column8: if members know what I mean
column9: when quality improvements are taken into account. We do not need to worry about competitors because the Americans
column10: the British and the Japanese are aiming for a figure of approximately 2%
column11: while some other countries are aiming for much higher rates. All of this will be sorted with exchange rates. An interesting question was asked about the distributional impact of quantitative easing. We discuss it frequently. It is simplistic to suggest the people who sell the bonds to the Central Bank will surely make the profit. That is an overly simplistic approach. As the effects of quantitative easing pass through the economy
column14: new jobs for people who do not have jobs and higher wages. They pass through the economy and the issue is being studied. I know from the recent INET conference I attended in Paris that some left-thinking people have been discussing whether there are better ways of engaging in quantitative easing. Consideration is being given to approaches that could result in a better distributional effect. There is a broad distributional impact
column15: but perhaps it could be done better. As Deputy Arthur Spring said
column16: we did not come to this until a certain point in time. Other countries had done it at an earlier stage. Yes
column17: there are different interests. Some governors and members of the governing council perceive some issues as having greater prominence than others. Countries in which the saving constituency is very dominant are not clear that they like quantitative easing at all
column18: with zero interest rates on their savings. Many considerations
column19: including legal issues and the question of compliance with the treaty
column20: were widely discussed. We tried all sorts of other tools. It was easier in a single country jurisdiction for the Americans to buy Federal Government guaranteed securities
column21: for the Bank of England to buy many British Government securities or for the Bank of Japan to buy many Japanese Government bonds.People were looking at the monetary financing of Governments and wondering if they could really do this. There were a lot of legal considerations and concerns. We got there

column24: I should rephrase that because the Central Bank does other things. What the Government has managed to achieve is a refinancing of that cost at these extremely low interest rates. The capitalised value of that refinancing is the €9 billion or €10 billion sum. That is why it is so difficult
